column1: San José de Mayo (Spanish pronunciation: [saŋ xoˈse ðe ˈmaʝo]) is the capital city of the San José Department in southern Uruguay.
The city is located at the centre of the state
column2: on the intersection of Route 3 with Route 11
column3: 90 kilometres (56 mi) from the centre of Montevideo. The railroad track connecting Montevideo with Colonia and with the northwest of the country passes through the city. The river Río San José flows along the northeastern and eastern limits of the city.

column1: San José de Mayo was founded on 1 July 1783. It had acquired "Villa" (town) status before the Independence of Uruguay
column2: which was elevated to "Ciudad" (city) on 12 July 1856 by the Act of Ley Nº 495. During the 19th century it became a commercial and cultural centre
column3: known as "Montevideo chico" ("little Montevideo"). The theatre "Teatro Macció" was constructed at the turn of the 20th century.

column1: In 2011 San José de Mayo had a population of 36
Source: Instituto Nacional de Estadística de Uruguay
Cathedral Basilica and National Sanctuary of St. Joseph (Roman Catholic)
Our Lady of the Rosary of Pompei Parish Church (Roman Catholic)
Our Lady of Fatima Parish Church (Roman Catholic)
Our Lady of the Orchard Chapel (Roman Catholic)
Besides being the administrative capital of the department
column2: the city is an active regional commercial and financial centre. Its economy is linked mainly to cattle ranching
column3: and it is an agro-industrial centre for dairy products
